conclusion: Consider the Ampere force on each resistance wire and sum them to find the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires.
The resistance wires are arranged in an equilateral triangular frame.
Points A and B are connected to the two ends of a power supply with a constant voltage.
The current passes through the AB section of the resistance wire.
The Ampere force on a resistance wire is given by the equation F = (μ0 * I * L) / 2.
μ0 is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^-7 T·m/A), I is the current through the wire, L is the length of the wire.
The length of each resistance wire is equal to the side length of the equilateral triangle.
The side length of an equilateral triangle with side length s is given by s = (√3/2) * s.
The length of each resistance wire is L = (√3/2) * s.
The current through each resistance wire is constant and equal to the voltage divided by the resistance of the wire.
The resistance of each resistance wire is equal to the resistance of the triangular frame.
The resistance of the triangular frame is given by a complex formula involving multiple √3/2 terms.
